qas.question: Who complained that Brasilia was monotonous?

answers.text: its cuisine and efficiency of transit

plausible_answers.text: its superquadras exuded "the same air of elegant monotony,"

qas.question: What did the citizens complain after visiting Brasilia?
What have other observers compared forested areas to?

plausible_answers.text: small commercial areas, bookstores and cafes

qas.question: What is located on either side of the plazas?
How have the bookstores and cafes been improved?

context: After a visit to Brasília, the <a1_0>French<a1_0/> <a2_0>writer<a2_0/> <a0_0>Simone de Beauvoir<a0_0/> complained that all of <b4_0>its superquadras exuded "the same air of elegant monotony,"<b4_0/> and other observers have equated the city's large open lawns, plazas, and fields to <b6_0>wastelands<b6_0/>. As the city has matured, some of these have gained adornments, and many have been improved by <b8_0>landscaping<b8_0/>, giving some observers a sense of "humanized" spaciousness. Although not fully accomplished, the "Brasília utopia" has produced a city of relatively high quality of life, in which the citizens live in forested areas with sporting and leisure structure (the superquadras) flanked by <b7_0>small commercial areas, bookstores and cafes<b7_0/>; the city is famous for <a3_0>its <b5_0>cuisine and efficiency of transit<b5_0/><a3_0/>.
